title: Face Inventory
description: How many versions of you exist?

traits.fractured: Exists in broken pieces, each fragment reflecting different truths
traits.actor: Master performer who has forgotten their original role
traits.chameleon: Shape-shifter who transforms completely based on environment
traits.hollow: Empty vessel that fills itself with echoes of others
traits.legion: Multiple distinct identities sharing one body

questions.question: When you walk into a party where you don't know anyone, which version of you shows up?

answers.text: A scattered mix of different pieces depending on who I talk to first
Whoever I think will be most impressive or likeable to this crowd
A version that rapidly adapts and shifts based on the energy I pick up
Whichever internal person volunteers to handle social situations
An empty shell that borrows personality from whoever seems interesting

questions.question: Your dating profile probably makes you sound like a completely different person because:

answers.text: I can only show fragments of myself and they don't always match up
I'm performing the role of 'ideal romantic partner' rather than being myself
I become whoever I think will attract the most interesting matches
Different parts of me wrote different sections and they don't coordinate
I'm desperately trying to sound like someone who actually exists

questions.question: When your family describes you to other people, you cringe because:

answers.text: They're describing pieces of me that don't connect to who I am now
They're talking about a character I played for them, not the real me
That version of me only exists when I'm around them specifically
They're describing just one of many people who live in my body
They're describing someone who doesn't actually exist anymore

questions.question: Your biggest fear during job interviews is:

answers.text: The different parts of my personality will contradict each other
I'll break character and they'll see I'm just performing competence
I'll adapt so much to what they want that I'll lose track of what I can actually do
The wrong internal person will show up to represent our qualifications
They'll realize there's nobody actually qualified hiding behind the performance

questions.question: When you're having a bad mental health day, it feels like:

answers.text: All my pieces are scattered and I can't put them back together
I'm too exhausted to maintain any of my usual performances
I don't know who to be when I'm not adapting to someone else's needs
There's chaos and conflict happening between my internal selves
The emptiness becomes impossible to ignore or cover up

questions.question: Your Spotify playlist makes no sense to other people because:

answers.text: Different fragments of me love completely different music styles
I've curated songs for different characters I need to embody
My taste in music changes based on who I've been hanging around
Each internal person has their own musical preferences and they're all mixed together
I don't actually like any of it, I just collected songs that seemed like things I should enjoy

questions.question: When someone says 'just be yourself' on a first date, your internal reaction is:

answers.text: Panic about which fragmented version they want to see
Amusement because there is no authentic self to reveal
Confusion about which adapted version would work best here
An internal meeting to decide who should handle this date
Terror because there's nothing authentic underneath to show them

questions.question: Your biggest struggle with social media is:

answers.text: Different aspects of my personality conflict in what I want to post
Maintaining a consistent character across all my posts and interactions
My online personality shifts depending on who I think is watching
Different internal selves want to use the account for completely different purposes
Everything I post feels fake because there's no real person behind it

questions.question: When you look at photos of yourself from different time periods, it's like:

answers.text: Seeing a timeline of fragmented selves that don't quite connect
Reviewing a portfolio of different characters I've successfully portrayed
Watching my shape-shifting abilities evolve over different life phases
Meeting old friends who used to live in my body
Looking at elaborate costumes that were never hiding a real person

questions.question: Your friends get confused when they hear stories about you from other friend groups because:

answers.text: They're hearing about different broken pieces of who I am
I perform completely different roles for different social circles
I become an entirely different version of myself in each group
Different internal people take charge in different social contexts
I'm hollow enough that each group projects their own version onto me

questions.question: When someone asks about your childhood personality, you:

answers.text: Remember fragments that feel disconnected from who I became
Realize that even as a kid I was performing for different audiences
Remember being a different person in every situation even then
Can identify which current internal selves were present back then
Feel like I'm describing a character from a book I read once

questions.question: Your biggest relationship red flag is probably:

answers.text: I'll show you different fragments of myself and they might contradict each other
I'll become whoever I think you want me to be instead of being authentic
I'll adapt so completely to your energy that I'll lose myself in you
You'll have to navigate relationships with multiple people in one body
You'll fall in love with an illusion because there's nobody real underneath

questions.question: When you're home alone with no plans, you:

answers.text: Feel my scattered pieces floating around without direction
Keep performing for an imaginary audience because I can't stop
Feel lost without external cues telling me who to be
Have internal conversations between different aspects of myself
Confront the uncomfortable silence where a personality should be

questions.question: Your therapist probably gets frustrated because:

answers.text: I bring different pieces of myself to different sessions
I perform the role of 'good therapy client' instead of being real
I adapt to what I think they want to hear rather than sharing authentically
They're trying to treat multiple people with different needs and histories
There's no core self to heal or understand underneath all the performance

questions.question: When you're drunk or high, the scariest thing is:

answers.text: All my fragmented pieces start talking at once and nothing makes sense
I lose control of my performance and people see the chaos underneath
I can't read the room anymore so I don't know who to become
Different internal selves might take control without warning
The emptiness becomes impossible to hide or distract from

questions.question: Your online shopping cart is chaotic because:

answers.text: Different fragments of me want completely different things
I'm buying costumes and props for different characters I need to play
My style and preferences shift based on whose aesthetic I'm copying
Multiple internal people are adding items for their individual needs
I'm desperately buying things hoping they'll help me feel like a real person

questions.question: When someone compliments your personality, you think:

answers.text: Which broken piece of me were they seeing in that moment?
They're praising my acting skills without realizing it
They like the version of me that emerged in response to their energy
They met one of my internal selves and connected with them specifically
They're complimenting an illusion that doesn't actually exist

questions.question: Your worst nightmare about being truly seen is:

answers.text: Someone realizing all my pieces don't add up to a whole person
Getting caught mid-performance and having my act completely exposed
Someone seeing through my adaptations to whatever nothing exists underneath
People being overwhelmed by discovering how many of us live in here
Someone looking for the real me and finding absolutely nothing there

questions.question: When you try to make important life decisions, the biggest problem is:

answers.text: Different fragments of me want incompatible things
I don't know which character should be making this choice
My preferences change depending on who I'm talking to about it
I need to get consensus from multiple internal voices with different agendas
Nothing feels authentically wanted when there's no authentic self to want it

questions.question: Your voice and mannerisms change so much that:

answers.text: People notice different aspects of my personality coming through
I sound like different actors playing the same role
I unconsciously mirror whoever I'm talking to or thinking about
Different internal people have distinctly different ways of speaking
I cycle through voices hoping one will sound convincingly real

questions.question: When you're in a group chat, you:

answers.text: Let different pieces of my personality respond to different people
Carefully curate my responses to match the group's energy and expectations
Adapt my communication style to whatever vibe is happening in the moment
Have internal negotiations about who should respond to each message
Type and delete responses because nothing feels authentically mine to say

questions.question: Your Google search history would confuse people because:

answers.text: It reflects the scattered interests of different aspects of myself
I research how to convincingly portray different types of people
My interests shift completely based on who I've been around lately
Multiple internal people use it for completely different purposes
I'm constantly searching for clues about how to be a convincing human being

questions.question: When people ask what your 'type' is in romantic partners, you:

answers.text: Realize different parts of me are attracted to completely different people
Know I'm attracted to people I can create compelling performances for
Am drawn to whoever brings out the most interesting version of myself
Have multiple internal people with completely different romantic preferences
Am attracted to people who might make me feel like I actually exist

questions.question: If all your different selves had a group text, what would it look like?

answers.text: Scattered messages that don't quite connect into coherent conversations
A director giving notes to various actors about their performances
Messages that constantly shift tone and style mid-conversation
A chaotic group chat with distinct personalities debating everything
A bunch of empty profiles sending echo messages with no real content

questions.question: When you answer 'Who am I really?' the honest response is:

answers.text: A puzzle with missing pieces that might never form a complete picture
A master performer who has been acting for so long they forgot their original role
A shape-shifter whose original form is lost in all the adaptations
A collection of people sharing space who are still figuring out how to coexist
A question mark in human form, an absence pretending to be a presence

fractured.title: The Fractured Mirror
fractured.description: Your identity exists in scattered pieces, each fragment reflecting a different truth. You're not one person pretending to be many - you're many pieces fighting to become whole.
fractured.extended:
Your identity exists as a collection of shattered fragments, each piece containing a different aspect of who you are, but none of them quite connecting into a complete whole. Unlike those who wear masks or perform roles, your different aspects feel genuinely disconnected from each other - sometimes conflicting, sometimes contradictory, always struggling to form a coherent sense of self.

You might notice that different situations bring out completely different versions of you, and these versions don't always recognize or understand each other. Your work self might make decisions your home self disagrees with, or your social self might commit to things your private self has no interest in following through on. This isn't conscious role-playing; it's more like different radio stations broadcasting on the same frequency, creating static and confusion.

The frustrating part is that each fragment contains genuine pieces of who you are - they're not fake or performed, just incomplete. You long for integration, for these scattered aspects to somehow communicate and coordinate, creating a unified sense of self that feels both coherent and authentic. The challenge is learning to see the pattern in the mosaic rather than mourning the cracks between the pieces.

Your fragmentation isn't a flaw to be fixed but a complexity to be understood. Many people who feel fractured are actually highly sensitive individuals who have developed multiple coping strategies for different environments. The goal isn't to eliminate your various aspects but to help them work together more harmoniously, creating internal collaboration rather than competition.

actor.title: The Method Actor
actor.description: Life is your stage, and you've forgotten which role was originally yours. Every interaction is a performance, every relationship a carefully scripted scene where you've become the master of being whoever others need you to be.
actor.extended:
You have developed such sophisticated skills in reading situations and becoming what's needed that performance has become your default mode of being. Unlike those who consciously choose to act differently in different situations, your transformations happen automatically - you assess what each interaction requires and seamlessly become that version of yourself without even thinking about it.

Your performances are so convincing that even you sometimes believe them, but there's always a part of you that remains aware you're playing a role. You've become a master method actor, so deeply immersed in each character that you can genuinely feel their emotions and motivations. The problem is that you've been performing for so long that you're no longer sure where the acting ends and your authentic self begins.

This isn't simple people-pleasing or manipulation - it's a highly developed survival strategy that has likely served you well in many situations. You can navigate complex social dynamics, make others feel comfortable, and adapt to new environments with remarkable skill. However, the exhaustion of constant performance and the loneliness of feeling unseen for who you really are can be overwhelming.

The path forward involves gradually experimenting with moments of authenticity - small breaks in the performance where you allow your genuine reactions and preferences to show through. This doesn't mean abandoning your adaptive skills, but rather learning to choose when to perform and when to simply be. Your gift for reading others and adapting can become a conscious tool rather than an unconscious compulsion.

chameleon.title: The Social Chameleon
chameleon.description: You don't just adapt - you transform completely. Your personality flows like liquid into whatever shape each moment requires, making you a master of social survival through constant metamorphosis.
chameleon.extended:
Your adaptation goes far beyond surface-level adjustments - you undergo complete transformations that affect your interests, values, communication style, and even your emotional responses. You don't consciously decide to become different; instead, you unconsciously absorb and mirror the energy, preferences, and characteristics of whatever environment or people you're around.

This isn't mere people-pleasing but rather a sophisticated form of social intelligence that allows you to genuinely connect with almost anyone. You can become fascinated by topics you've never considered before if someone passionate introduces them to you, and you can shift your entire worldview based on compelling new perspectives you encounter. Your adaptability is so complete that you can feel authentic in many different versions of yourself.

The challenge lies in the fluidity itself - when you can become anyone, it becomes difficult to know who you are when you're alone. Your preferences, opinions, and even your sense of what you enjoy can shift so dramatically that you lose track of any consistent core identity. You might find yourself wondering which version of you is 'real' or whether there's an original self underneath all the adaptations.

Your chameleon nature is actually a remarkable form of emotional and social intelligence, but it needs some grounding. The goal isn't to become rigid or stop adapting, but to develop a flexible core of values and preferences that can bend without breaking. Think of it as becoming a river rather than a puddle - maintaining flow and adaptability while having a consistent direction and character.

hollow.title: The Hollow Vessel
hollow.description: Where others have identity, you have absence. You're not fractured or performing - you're fundamentally empty, a human-shaped void that fills itself with echoes of others while questioning whether you truly exist.
hollow.extended:
Your experience of identity is fundamentally different from most people - rather than feeling like you have a self that's hidden, fragmented, or performed, you experience yourself as essentially empty. This isn't depression or low self-esteem, but rather a profound sense that where other people have a core identity, you have a void. You feel like a container that takes the shape of whatever fills it, but remains empty when alone.

This hollowness often manifests as feeling like you're simulating human experiences rather than genuinely having them. Your emotions might feel borrowed from other people's lives, your interests adopted rather than authentic, and your reactions learned rather than spontaneous. You may sometimes wonder if you're actually a real person or just a very convincing imitation of one.

The existential weight of this experience can be profound - you're constantly questioning your own reality and authenticity in ways that most people never have to consider. Social interactions can feel like elaborate performances where you're desperately trying to convince others (and yourself) that there's someone actually home behind your eyes.

Your emptiness, while painful, may actually be a different form of spiritual or psychological openness. Many wisdom traditions speak of emptiness as a state of pure potential rather than absence. Your void might be space for possibilities rather than evidence of deficiency. Instead of trying to fill the emptiness, consider whether learning to be comfortable with it might reveal a different kind of fullness - one based on presence rather than content.

legion.title: The Legion Self
legion.description: You are not one, you are many. Multiple distinct identities share your body, each with their own personalities, memories, and agendas. You're less a person than a democracy of selves trying to coexist.
legion.extended:
Your internal experience is that of housing multiple complete individuals rather than different aspects of one person. These aren't masks or fragments but fully formed identities with their own personalities, preferences, memories, and ways of interacting with the world. You experience life as an internal community where different selves negotiate for time, make decisions collectively, and sometimes disagree about direction and priorities.

Your different selves might have distinct relationships with the same people, separate interests and hobbies, and even different ways of speaking and moving through the world. You may find yourself having internal conversations, debates, or even conflicts between these various identities. Some may be more prominent in certain situations while others prefer to remain in the background.

This multiplicity can be both a gift and a challenge. On one hand, you have access to diverse perspectives, skills, and ways of being that can make you incredibly adaptable and resourceful. Different selves might excel in different areas, creating a rich internal resource system. On the other hand, coordination and decision-making can be complex when multiple voices need to be heard and considered.

Rather than viewing your plurality as something to eliminate, consider it as a unique form of consciousness that requires different management strategies than singular identity. Focus on developing good internal communication, establishing frameworks for decision-making, and creating cooperation rather than competition between your various selves. Your legion nature might be an evolution beyond traditional single-identity consciousness rather than a deviation from it.
